# Documentation Standards

## General Guidelines

- Write clear, concise, and accurate documentation
- Use proper Markdown formatting and structure
- Include code examples where appropriate
- Keep documentation up to date with code changes
- Use inclusive and accessible language

## README Files

- Include a clear project description
- Provide installation and setup instructions
- Document usage examples and common use cases
- List prerequisites and dependencies
- Include contribution guidelines if applicable
- Add badges for build status, coverage, etc.

## Code Comments

- Write comments that explain "why", not "what"
- Document complex algorithms and business logic
- Use docstrings for functions, classes, and modules
- Keep comments concise and relevant
- Update comments when code changes

## API Documentation

- Document all public APIs and interfaces
- Include parameter types and return values
- Provide usage examples
- Document error conditions and exceptions
- Keep API docs versioned and synchronized

## Technical Writing

- Use active voice
- Be consistent with terminology
- Structure content with headings and sections
- Use lists and tables for better readability
- Include diagrams for complex concepts

## Examples

- Provide realistic, working examples
- Include both simple and advanced use cases
- Ensure examples are tested and up to date
- Comment examples to explain key concepts
- Show error handling patterns
